awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project - Improving Pathways for STEM Retention and Graduation (IPSRG)
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in STEM and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at Central State University seeks to build on previous successful efforts to increase participation of African-American students in STEM disciplines. The institution seeks to address low first year retention and persistence in the STEM areas. Central State University recognizes that the need to improve learning practices must be addressed. To address the issue of high unemployment levels for veterans in the state of Ohio, Central State University will increase educational opportunities for veterans in STEM fields.

The goal of the project is to improve retention and persistence rates by adopting evidence-based strategies to include: enhancement of the university's cyber-infrastructure for "anytime, anywhere, anyone learning"; development and assessment of innovative teaching and learning techniques in STEM curricula; enhancement of undergraduate student research experiences; faculty professional development in effective STEM teaching pedagogy and research; and the creation of new approaches to recruitment and retention of undergraduate STEM students. Through the evaluation plan, the impact of infusion of cyber-pedagogy and integration of experiential learning on traditional students and veterans will be studied and disseminated.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the NSF Improving Pathways for STEM Retention and Graduation (IPSRG) program was to increase the number of STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Agriculture, and Mathematics) majors, including military associated students, who successfully entered the workforce or pursued advanced STEAM degrees by increasing the recruitment, retention, persistence, and graduation rates through enhanced quality student experiences and remediating gap areas.

The overarching theme of the IPSRG program was to improve retention and persistence rates by adopting evidence-based techniques including: 

*Enhancing Central State University's (CSU) cyber infrastructure for anytime, anywhere, anyone learning;
*Developing and accessing innovative STEAM curriculum teaching and learning techniques;
*Enhancing undergraduate student research experiences;
*Providing faculty professional development in effective STEAM teaching pedagogy and research; and
*Creating new approaches to recruitment and retention of undergraduate STEAM students.

The following objectives guided the success of the program:

*Increase the retention rate of freshmen STEAM majors from 51% to 72% at graduated rates of 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9% per year.
*Increase the graduation rate of STEAM majors from 21% to 39%.
*Increase persistence rates of STEAM majors through the Junior year from 24% to 39% at graduated rates of 10% per year.
*Increase the number of students engaging in undergraduate research and capstone courses.
*Increase the number of Military associated STEAM majors.
*Increase the number of students entering graduate school upon graduation.

The depth and breadth of activities that contributed to successful student experiences and results included:

Infrastructure Improvement

*Up-to-date instructional technology was incorporated into classrooms across the college where STEAM gateway courses were taught.
*The institution upgraded internet connectivity and bandwidth across the campus.

Instructor Professional Development

*Workshops were offered to faculty to improve teaching effectiveness using Learning Management Software (LMS) and incorporating hybrid or flipped class teaching models.
*IPSRG partnered with a collaborating program on campus to offer and encourage faculty participation with the Mobile Summer Institute (MoSI) on Scientific Teaching workshops and training offered on campus.

Student Tutoring Support

*IPSRG partnered with Wright State University to offer online tutoring for students.
*IPSRG returned to traditional and peer tutoring after online tutoring provided less than expected results.

Engaging Students in Research

*The IPSRG Team liaised with faculty mentors and undergraduate students for successful research project outcomes.
*Initial momentum in the number of undergraduate research projects each year increased exponentially.
*A hurdle that had to be taken was faculty's desire for greater incentives before agreeing to mentor students.
*The COVID-19 pandemic significantly slowed the growth in undergraduate research participation.

Development of Students

*Professional development activities for students included field trips to business partners, graduate school opportunities, guest speakers, conferences, tutoring, etc.
*Students' motivation and activity levels were markedly increased and improved when they were part of a community of peers and mentors devoted to their own improvement through self-direction and guided objectives.  IPSRG created a successful Community of Practice (CoP).

Intellectual Merits and Broader Impacts

Observation indicates there is strong evidence that student success for STEAM majors is not dependent on specific technology or teaching models.

Novel technology and new models of teaching/learning are not a promise of STEAM student success. However, there is sufficient data to provide evidence that instructional technology advances and new models of teaching/learning coupled with hands-on learning and mentoring may be major factors in supporting the academic success of students.

Also, when students assembled together focused on educational and life goals, a dynamic developed where, collectively, students found the motivation and camaraderie to manifest positive advancements.  There are several keys to having such a dynamic emerge and be sustained:

*Students must be allowed to explore creative and autonomous thought processes and actions.
*Students must have the guidance of a set of mentors invested in directing the group toward successful experiences.
*Rapport must exist between students and mentors.
*Students and mentors must be willing to support each other through successful experiences over time.

While observing the dynamics of the Community of Practice (CoP) created through IPSRG, successful assemblies of students and mentors have the following characteristics:

*They Care
*They Connect, and
*They Cultivate

There is strong anecdotal evidence to suggest that students can and will be successful in STEAM majors, careers, and in most other areas of life when they are surrounded in a nurturing environment with caring mentors invested in allowing students to grow and develop through guided, autonomous experiences, and where all successes are celebrated by the assembly.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: Augustus Morris

Images (1 of )
  • Central State students and mentors take a break from the ERN Conference while sight seeing Washington D.C. A visit to the Lincoln Memorial stirred in each of us both introspection and promise. Learning in an experience-diverse community is a great antidote for polarization.
    Suzanne Marie
    Copyrighted
    Augustus Morris
    Together Great Things are Possible!
  • CSU senior Marshall Mullins shares the results of his research to others at the ERN Conference. He is one of nearly 100 students that had the experience of performing research under faculty mentors under the IPSRG program. Performing and disseminating their research builds self esteem and exposure.
    Suzanne Marie
    Copyrighted
    Augustus Morris
    Hard Work Pays Off.
  • IPSRG hosted an evening with industrial partners and Central State alumni to converse with the STEM majors. Topics included soft skill development, resume building and transitioning from the classroom to industry.
    Suzanne Marie
    Copyrighted
    Augustus Morris
    An Evening of Dialogue.
  • When students and their mentors explore new knowledge together, friendships are formed which last forever. The research of Jada Smith and her mentor, Dr. Hongmei Li-Byarlay, will be used to prevent the decline of the honey bee population necessary for global food production.
    Suzanne Marie
    Copyrighted
    Augustus Morris
    Strong Bonds Cannot be Broken
  • IPSRG and Verizon partnered together to develop a year round STEM mentoring program for middle school males. Central State STEM majors took the opportunity to mentor these young men just as they have been mentored. This culminated in the celebration of success with parents and family.
    Suzanne Marie
    Copyrighted
    Augustus Morris
    The Mentored Became Mentors
  • The message is clear. When students and mentors of all ages work toward the same goals, success is assured when there is commitment to guiding, learning from, and celebrating each other. This collective of guided curiosity, motivation, and potential within a group is the key to success in anything.
    Suzanne Marie
    Copyrighted
    Augustus Morris
    We Care, We Connect, We Cultivate
